description: This course takes a look at how businesses find, evaluate and implement emerging and disruptive technologies. Emerging technologies tend to carry a high risk level, but the reward is often a competitive advantage that can solidify an organization's hold on the marketplace. This course demonstrates techniques to help identify ideal innovation candidates and to fully exploit their potential to the benefit of an organization.
descriptionMD: This course takes a look at how businesses find, evaluate and implement emerging and disruptive technologies. Emerging technologies tend to carry a high risk level, but the reward is often a competitive advantage that can solidify an organization's hold on the marketplace. This course demonstrates techniques to help identify ideal innovation candidates and to fully exploit their potential to the benefit of an organization.
name: Emerging Technologies
subtitle: Emerging and Disruptive Technologies in the Workplace

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don introduce you to the Gartner STREET process, which is used to evaluate the viability of a new technology's integration into your environment.
episodes.title: Introduction to the STREET Process
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:01.619
Welcome to ITPROTV.

2
00:00:01.619 --> 00:00:06.675
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.675 --> 00:00:10.498
>> You're watching ITPROTV.

4
00:00:10.498 --> 00:00:12.720
>> All right, greetings everyone, and

5
00:00:12.720 --> 00:00:15.439
welcome to another great
episode of ITPROTV.

6
00:00:15.439 --> 00:00:19.348
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie, and
in today's episode we're gonna take

7
00:00:19.348 --> 00:00:23.470
a look at emerging technology,
specifically the Gartner STREET process.

8
00:00:23.470 --> 00:00:27.566
Joining us in the studio to help lend his
expertise on that topic, our good friend,

9
00:00:27.566 --> 00:00:28.395
Mr. Don Pezet.

10
00:00:28.395 --> 00:00:29.008
Don, welcome to the show, sir.

11
00:00:29.008 --> 00:00:30.286
How's it going today?

12
00:00:30.286 --> 00:00:30.919
>> It is going great, Daniel.

13
00:00:30.919 --> 00:00:32.240
Ready to dive right into this one.

14
00:00:32.240 --> 00:00:36.472
And for those of you that aren't familiar
with it, the Gartner STREET process is

15
00:00:36.472 --> 00:00:40.395
really a neat framework that helps us
to evaluate emerging technologies,

16
00:00:40.395 --> 00:00:43.900
to determine whether or
not they're right for our organization.

17
00:00:43.900 --> 00:00:45.700
And so in this episode,
we're gonna run through that process.

18
00:00:45.700 --> 00:00:49.572
We're gonna learn about the different
steps, kinda see what's involved, and help

19
00:00:49.572 --> 00:00:53.446
us to make better decisions when it comes
to evaluating, and ultimately selecting,

20
00:00:53.446 --> 00:00:56.281
an emerging technology to put
it in use inside of our company.

21
00:00:56.281 --> 00:01:00.770
>> All right, well Don, we've thrown
around that term, emerging technologies.

22
00:01:00.770 --> 00:01:03.377
I think a good place to start would be,
what is an emerging technology?

23
00:01:03.377 --> 00:01:06.915
>> All right, and that's really important,
because this whole course is about that.

24
00:01:06.915 --> 00:01:09.034
But Gartner actually has
a very specific definition for

25
00:01:09.034 --> 00:01:10.669
what they feel is an emerging technology.

26
00:01:10.669 --> 00:01:14.808
So let me bring up here on my system
what their official definition is for

27
00:01:14.808 --> 00:01:16.328
an emerging technology.

28
00:01:16.328 --> 00:01:21.261
It is those technologies that are not yet
mature in the marketplace and

29
00:01:21.261 --> 00:01:24.280
so entail a higher-than-average risk.

30
00:01:24.280 --> 00:01:27.341
Right, we could translate
that as meaning anything new.

31
00:01:27.341 --> 00:01:29.967
>> [LAUGH]
>> If there's something new that has

32
00:01:29.967 --> 00:01:33.257
only been out for a brief while, it's
cutting edge, bleeding edge technology.

33
00:01:33.257 --> 00:01:34.616
It might be great.

34
00:01:34.616 --> 00:01:37.969
It might be the next big thing.

35
00:01:37.969 --> 00:01:41.912
But for every great success that's
out there, there are failures, and

36
00:01:41.912 --> 00:01:43.410
usually a lot of failures.

37
00:01:43.410 --> 00:01:48.285
And there's nothing worse than making
a substantial financial investment

38
00:01:48.285 --> 00:01:51.179
in a technology,
only to have it collapse and

39
00:01:51.179 --> 00:01:54.009
no longer be in use,
no longer be relevant.

40
00:01:54.009 --> 00:01:57.552
>> Now, Don, is emerging technologies
the same as disruptive technologies?

41
00:01:57.552 --> 00:02:00.065
>> I'm glad you mentioned that,
Daniel, cuz the two terms,

42
00:02:00.065 --> 00:02:01.329
they get interchanged a lot.

43
00:02:01.329 --> 00:02:02.962
You'll see a lot of sites and

44
00:02:02.962 --> 00:02:06.106
texts that'll actually just
use them synonymously.

45
00:02:06.106 --> 00:02:07.797
And they are actually different, right?

46
00:02:07.797 --> 00:02:08.872
Subtly different, but they are different.

47
00:02:08.872 --> 00:02:13.170
So there's not really an official
disruptive technology definition, but

48
00:02:13.170 --> 00:02:16.137
Margaret Rouse had a really
good definition for it.

49
00:02:16.137 --> 00:02:20.692
She said it's one that displaces
an established technology and

50
00:02:20.692 --> 00:02:22.462
shakes up the industry or

51
00:02:22.462 --> 00:02:28.046
a ground-breaking product that creates
a completely new industry, right?

52
00:02:28.046 --> 00:02:32.601
And if you think about that, every now and
then, there's something that comes out

53
00:02:32.601 --> 00:02:35.531
that really changes the way
that people do business,

54
00:02:35.531 --> 00:02:38.413
that really just completely
shakes up an industry.

55
00:02:38.413 --> 00:02:42.720
So, for example, take universities, right?

56
00:02:42.720 --> 00:02:45.838
When I was in college,
you physically went to the university, and

57
00:02:45.838 --> 00:02:47.243
attended class right there.

58
00:02:47.243 --> 00:02:48.522
The professor was in the room with you.

59
00:02:48.522 --> 00:02:49.927
And that's how you learned.

60
00:02:49.927 --> 00:02:51.534
And that was the only option.

61
00:02:51.534 --> 00:02:52.812
There were no other choices.

62
00:02:52.812 --> 00:02:54.706
But, look at university students today.

63
00:02:54.706 --> 00:02:57.177
We have so many choices available to you.

64
00:02:57.177 --> 00:02:58.203
You can do online training.

65
00:02:58.203 --> 00:02:59.355
You can do in person.

66
00:02:59.355 --> 00:03:00.550
You can do hybrid, where it's both.

67
00:03:00.550 --> 00:03:03.610
You can do synchronous and asynchronous,
so many different choices.

68
00:03:03.610 --> 00:03:06.988
And a lot of that is due to disruptive
technologies, ones that came and

69
00:03:06.988 --> 00:03:08.888
really shuffled up that marketplace.

70
00:03:08.888 --> 00:03:12.740
You'll see technologies
like electronic cars,

71
00:03:12.740 --> 00:03:18.430
where you had the Toyota Prius or
the Tesla, where it's fully electric.

72
00:03:18.430 --> 00:03:20.770
What's that doing to the oil industry?

73
00:03:20.770 --> 00:03:23.316
It's really disrupting
their business model.

74
00:03:23.316 --> 00:03:25.649
And eventually it'll ultimately
destroy that business model.

75
00:03:25.649 --> 00:03:26.347
That's disruptive.

76
00:03:26.347 --> 00:03:31.062
But an emerging technology doesn't
have to be disruptive, right?

77
00:03:31.062 --> 00:03:34.896
Every disruptive technology was
emerging at some point, right?

78
00:03:34.896 --> 00:03:37.051
So you can kind of use
that interchangeably.

79
00:03:37.051 --> 00:03:40.182
But every emerging technology
is not necessarily disruptive.

80
00:03:40.182 --> 00:03:43.842
Sometimes there's new things that
come out that they make life better.

81
00:03:43.842 --> 00:03:46.596
They help you achieve your goal,
but it's still the same goal,

82
00:03:46.596 --> 00:03:47.930
it's still the same process.

83
00:03:47.930 --> 00:03:48.842
It didn't really disrupt.

84
00:03:48.842 --> 00:03:50.493
So be careful with those two terms.

85
00:03:50.493 --> 00:03:54.921
So they are subtly different in
the way they can be used and

86
00:03:54.921 --> 00:03:56.774
the way that they mean.

87
00:03:56.774 --> 00:03:58.581
>> All right, Don.
Well, how does the STREET process

88
00:03:58.581 --> 00:04:01.123
help us when dealing with
emerging technologies?

89
00:04:01.123 --> 00:04:04.003
>> All right, well,
the STREET process actually breaks this

90
00:04:04.003 --> 00:04:06.840
up into six different steps,
right, it's a framework.

91
00:04:06.840 --> 00:04:10.804
And it's designed for
you to step through it, step by step,

92
00:04:10.804 --> 00:04:14.014
to evaluate a new technology
that's out there.

93
00:04:14.014 --> 00:04:16.271
And so I've got up here on the screen
that the STREET process and

94
00:04:16.271 --> 00:04:17.430
kind of the way that it lays out.

95
00:04:17.430 --> 00:04:19.935
And let me just do a quick
high level overview of it, and

96
00:04:19.935 --> 00:04:23.164
then we'll kinda dive into each step
in a little more detail, right?

97
00:04:23.164 --> 00:04:27.363
Basically, we start with
what's called the scope step.

98
00:04:27.363 --> 00:04:32.818
And the scope step is where we start to
evaluate what our business need is, right?

99
00:04:32.818 --> 00:04:34.000
Every company has needs, and

100
00:04:34.000 --> 00:04:36.944
you might be able to do something
better if you had certain technologies.

101
00:04:36.944 --> 00:04:39.207
You're not even worried about what
the technology is at this point.

102
00:04:39.207 --> 00:04:41.118
Just what is my need?

103
00:04:41.118 --> 00:04:42.723
And from there, we go into track.

104
00:04:42.723 --> 00:04:45.659
And we can track new,
emerging technologies, right?

105
00:04:45.659 --> 00:04:47.800
What's new?
What's out there in the industry?

106
00:04:47.800 --> 00:04:48.878
What might be able to
meet a business need?

107
00:04:48.878 --> 00:04:51.332
What aligns with my scope?

108
00:04:51.332 --> 00:04:53.710
And see how the arrows go back and
forth, right?

109
00:04:53.710 --> 00:04:56.500
I might have a business need,
and I look for a solution.

110
00:04:56.500 --> 00:04:58.550
And that's tracking, right?

111
00:04:58.550 --> 00:05:01.258
Or I might find a solution, and
then look for the business need.

112
00:05:01.258 --> 00:05:02.242
I might go the other way around.

113
00:05:02.242 --> 00:05:04.251
>> [LAUGH]
>> Somebody comes to me and says, Don,

114
00:05:04.251 --> 00:05:05.502
if you're not using product x,

115
00:05:05.502 --> 00:05:08.823
you're really doing yourself a disservice-
>> You're talking about a hammer looking

116
00:05:08.823 --> 00:05:09.511
for a nail right?

117
00:05:09.511 --> 00:05:10.665
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah, exactly!

118
00:05:10.665 --> 00:05:14.253
And so I need to go back and look at my
scope and then see, could I have that?

119
00:05:14.253 --> 00:05:16.410
Or maybe I need to reevaluate my scope.

120
00:05:16.410 --> 00:05:19.143
Maybe my company's vision of
the future is no longer the future.

121
00:05:19.143 --> 00:05:22.329
And I need to say, all right,
if we're going to stay relevant,

122
00:05:22.329 --> 00:05:24.043
how do we need to change and adapt?

123
00:05:24.043 --> 00:05:27.194
Now, once we've evaluated some
technologies that are out there,

124
00:05:27.194 --> 00:05:28.085
we move into rank.

125
00:05:28.085 --> 00:05:30.417
And in the rank step,
that's where we start looking,

126
00:05:30.417 --> 00:05:32.661
cuz there's maybe more than one solution,
right?

127
00:05:32.661 --> 00:05:34.021
So, which one is gonna be better for us?

128
00:05:34.021 --> 00:05:37.448
We need to rank them, and
categorize them, quantify, qualify,

129
00:05:37.448 --> 00:05:41.930
all the statistical things that we like to
do, and the just business case evaluation.

130
00:05:41.930 --> 00:05:43.383
All those things that we use to rank and

131
00:05:43.383 --> 00:05:45.299
determine which solution
is going to be the best.

132
00:05:45.299 --> 00:05:48.223
And that's gonna result
in innovation candidates.

133
00:05:48.223 --> 00:05:52.693
These are all potential
technologies that we could deploy.

134
00:05:52.693 --> 00:05:53.931
Some may be great.
Some may be poor.

135
00:05:53.931 --> 00:05:56.110
Some may have a future, some may not.

136
00:05:56.110 --> 00:05:57.840
We don't necessarily know.

137
00:05:57.840 --> 00:06:01.005
It's not until we get to the evaluate
step that we really find out.

138
00:06:01.005 --> 00:06:02.651
This is where we do our deep research.

139
00:06:02.651 --> 00:06:07.028
We really look into the technology and
try and answer any unanswered question,

140
00:06:07.028 --> 00:06:08.740
so that we can make a decision.

141
00:06:08.740 --> 00:06:11.093
Once we make a decision, we evangelize.

142
00:06:11.093 --> 00:06:13.764
We promote that technology
inside of our company.

143
00:06:13.764 --> 00:06:17.717
You wanna make sure that your employees,
your key stakeholders, your managers,

144
00:06:17.717 --> 00:06:20.154
that they all agree that
this is a good technology.

145
00:06:20.154 --> 00:06:23.157
They wanna use it, they wanna make
the company better by using it.

146
00:06:23.157 --> 00:06:24.753
If you don't have buy
in from the employees,

147
00:06:24.753 --> 00:06:27.283
it doesn't matter what tools you give
them or resources you give them.

148
00:06:27.283 --> 00:06:29.811
If they don't use them,
it's not going to succeed.

149
00:06:29.811 --> 00:06:32.533
And then at the end, we have transfer.

150
00:06:32.533 --> 00:06:37.521
Transfer is where the team that kind
of selected this technology hands

151
00:06:37.521 --> 00:06:40.575
off control of it to someone else, right?

152
00:06:40.575 --> 00:06:42.101
In the project management world,

153
00:06:42.101 --> 00:06:44.676
all of the STREET process will
be applied as a project, and

154
00:06:44.676 --> 00:06:48.322
then after the project is done, it becomes
what's called an ongoing operation.

155
00:06:48.322 --> 00:06:51.336
Somebody else takes over, and now they
run through it routinely and use it.

156
00:06:51.336 --> 00:06:53.367
That's what transfer is all about.

157
00:06:53.367 --> 00:06:56.479
And the person we transfer to may
come from within the team that does

158
00:06:56.479 --> 00:06:59.218
the selection,
it may be a completely different person.

159
00:06:59.218 --> 00:07:02.734
But we transfer it off and then we move
on to selecting our next product, right,

160
00:07:02.734 --> 00:07:04.160
our next emerging technology.

161
00:07:04.160 --> 00:07:08.033
So that's a high level overview
of how the STREET process works.

162
00:07:08.033 --> 00:07:12.399
And each step is designed to help us take
what could be a big problem or a big risk,

163
00:07:12.399 --> 00:07:15.350
and break it up into pieces so
it becomes manageable.

164
00:07:15.350 --> 00:07:19.684
We can make smart decisions along the way,
and ultimately make better decisions.

165
00:07:19.684 --> 00:07:20.558
>> All right, Don,

166
00:07:20.558 --> 00:07:23.890
we've seen the theory behind this
little STREET process of yours.

167
00:07:23.890 --> 00:07:26.237
How does that look when
we go onto the field?

168
00:07:26.237 --> 00:07:27.902
Can you give us an example of that?

169
00:07:27.902 --> 00:07:30.555
>> All right, so
let's create a fictitious company here.

170
00:07:30.555 --> 00:07:32.743
We're gonna do Rite Inspection Software,
right?

171
00:07:32.743 --> 00:07:35.892
They're a company, and
they make inspection software for

172
00:07:35.892 --> 00:07:37.724
doing home inspections, right?

173
00:07:37.724 --> 00:07:41.328
And their software is designed where
people can go out in the field,

174
00:07:41.328 --> 00:07:45.564
they can evaluate homes, or whatever,
come up with the building inspection,

175
00:07:45.564 --> 00:07:48.808
store it in a database, and
share that with their customer.

176
00:07:48.808 --> 00:07:53.354
Now this company is a mid-size company,
they're a Type B organization.

177
00:07:53.354 --> 00:07:55.454
And what that means is they're
not afraid to take risks.

178
00:07:55.454 --> 00:07:59.366
But they won't take a risk unless
they can actually justify it right?

179
00:07:59.366 --> 00:08:00.654
They got to have a business case.

180
00:08:00.654 --> 00:08:04.995
There's some companies,
some people like, who's that?

181
00:08:04.995 --> 00:08:06.434
Richard Branson, the Virgin guy?

182
00:08:06.434 --> 00:08:07.362
>> The Virgin guy, yeah.

183
00:08:07.362 --> 00:08:10.223
>> He'll take risks all over the place
because he's got a ton of money, right?

184
00:08:10.223 --> 00:08:10.837
>> [LAUGH]
>> And

185
00:08:10.837 --> 00:08:14.167
he knows the bigger the risk
the bigger the reward.

186
00:08:14.167 --> 00:08:18.847
But for most companies not taking risk
is not really an option because then you

187
00:08:18.847 --> 00:08:19.573
stagnate.

188
00:08:19.573 --> 00:08:22.268
You don't grow and
eventually you'll become obsolete.

189
00:08:22.268 --> 00:08:25.652
So a medium sized company will
often fall into this type B

190
00:08:25.652 --> 00:08:29.832
area where they will take risk as
long as they can justify it somehow.

191
00:08:29.832 --> 00:08:32.781
And if they choose to take the risk
they've already got the corporate skills

192
00:08:32.781 --> 00:08:35.005
and culture to be able to take
advantage of that, right?

193
00:08:35.005 --> 00:08:37.680
Small companies don't normally have
the corporate skills to do that.

194
00:08:37.680 --> 00:08:39.932
A medium size or larger would.

195
00:08:39.932 --> 00:08:43.912
So what they need is a solution for
a problem.

196
00:08:43.912 --> 00:08:47.253
And their problem doesn't
come from management.

197
00:08:47.253 --> 00:08:49.386
In this case their problem is actually
coming from the bottom of the company.

198
00:08:49.386 --> 00:08:51.865
It's coming from the workers,
and the SYS admins, and

199
00:08:51.865 --> 00:08:54.152
the people who are running
this software package.

200
00:08:54.152 --> 00:08:57.386
And they come and they say,
look we have a problem with storage.

201
00:08:57.386 --> 00:09:01.331
We have our servers and they all
have independent storage arrays or

202
00:09:01.331 --> 00:09:04.369
we might have SANS,
storage area networks setup.

203
00:09:04.369 --> 00:09:06.150
And there's different vendors and

204
00:09:06.150 --> 00:09:09.600
it's not mixed while it's becoming
very difficult to manage that.

205
00:09:09.600 --> 00:09:12.493
So we need to find some better
way to manage the storage for

206
00:09:12.493 --> 00:09:16.232
our data center, before we grow so
large that it becomes unmanageable and

207
00:09:16.232 --> 00:09:18.906
we ultimately have some kind
of failure as a result.

208
00:09:18.906 --> 00:09:23.293
So, they need to think about solutions
that could take care of the storage

209
00:09:23.293 --> 00:09:26.282
problem, that align with
their business goals.

210
00:09:26.282 --> 00:09:27.128
That's really important.

211
00:09:27.128 --> 00:09:31.348
Any solution, any emerging technology that
we adopt should somehow contribute to our

212
00:09:31.348 --> 00:09:32.224
business goals.

213
00:09:32.224 --> 00:09:34.315
And Rite Inspection Software?

214
00:09:34.315 --> 00:09:35.922
Has four simple goals, right?

215
00:09:35.922 --> 00:09:37.780
These are things they print,
they stick on their wall,

216
00:09:37.780 --> 00:09:39.172
it's on the back of their business card.

217
00:09:39.172 --> 00:09:41.317
These are the goals they attest to.

218
00:09:41.317 --> 00:09:43.605
One they wanna delight their customers,
right?

219
00:09:43.605 --> 00:09:46.433
When customers use their software they
should be happy to use it, right?

220
00:09:46.433 --> 00:09:47.116
It shouldn't be an uncomfortable.

221
00:09:47.116 --> 00:09:48.553
>> I like that one.
[LAUGH]

222
00:09:48.553 --> 00:09:49.556
>> Like any government website.

223
00:09:49.556 --> 00:09:51.113
>> Yeah.
>> So [LAUGH]

224
00:09:51.113 --> 00:09:53.259
>> It should be a pleasure to use.

225
00:09:53.259 --> 00:09:56.739
Two, they wanna seek innovative
solutions to promise, right?

226
00:09:56.739 --> 00:09:58.013
They don't mind taking a risk.

227
00:09:58.013 --> 00:10:00.855
They don't mind thinking outside
of the box to find a solution, so

228
00:10:00.855 --> 00:10:03.871

Does it actually look better?

00:20:30.569 --> 00:20:34.276
And you'll find that a lot of technologies
have a marketing slick that goes with them

461
00:20:34.276 --> 00:20:36.531
that says,
this is the greatest technology ever.

462
00:20:36.531 --> 00:20:37.768
You definitely need this.

463
00:20:37.768 --> 00:20:39.955
But what does that look like for you?

464
00:20:39.955 --> 00:20:40.904
Let me just give you an example here.

465
00:20:40.904 --> 00:20:42.365
I'm gonna pull up.

466
00:20:42.365 --> 00:20:44.200
Let's pretend like we were shopping.

467
00:20:44.200 --> 00:20:46.237
Software defined storage
can be really simple.

468
00:20:46.237 --> 00:20:47.926
Like Dropbox.

469
00:20:47.926 --> 00:20:48.993
I need storage.

470
00:20:48.993 --> 00:20:51.481
I go and I sign up with Dropbox,
it's I don't know, $100 a year or

471
00:20:51.481 --> 00:20:54.155
something like that and then you get
a terabyte of storage and there you go.

472
00:20:54.155 --> 00:20:59.723
But it's not super well
defined what's going on here.

473
00:20:59.723 --> 00:21:03.745
So for example, Dropbox For Business where
they tell you, you get unlimited storage.

474
00:21:03.745 --> 00:21:06.902
All right,
all my storage needs are now solved.

475
00:21:06.902 --> 00:21:07.777
Or is it?

476
00:21:07.777 --> 00:21:10.027
If I look at my vision of
how I would deploy it.

477
00:21:10.027 --> 00:21:11.368
All right, I have a database server.

478
00:21:11.368 --> 00:21:13.697
And the database server needs
two terabytes of storage.

479
00:21:13.697 --> 00:21:16.210
I can't put a database in Dropbox and
use it.

480
00:21:16.210 --> 00:21:17.313
It doesn't work that way.

481
00:21:17.313 --> 00:21:19.662
So I have to know how it works.

482
00:21:19.662 --> 00:21:21.622
I have to learn a little
more about the product.

483
00:21:21.622 --> 00:21:23.570
And if I start going to the other
vendors that are out there.

484
00:21:23.570 --> 00:21:25.163
If I go to Dell.

485
00:21:25.163 --> 00:21:26.444
Well, Dell will chat with me.

486
00:21:26.444 --> 00:21:26.987
Let me get rid of that.

487
00:21:26.987 --> 00:21:28.244
>> [LAUGH]
>> If I go to Dell,

488
00:21:28.244 --> 00:21:31.990
I can transform my infrastructure
with software defined storage.

489
00:21:31.990 --> 00:21:33.409
Transform.

490
00:21:33.409 --> 00:21:34.017
>> Mm.

491
00:21:34.017 --> 00:21:34.806
>> What does that even mean?

492
00:21:34.806 --> 00:21:36.445
>> [LAUGH]
>> It means it's gonna change.

493
00:21:36.445 --> 00:21:38.241
Of course it's gonna change,
I'm putting something new in.

494
00:21:38.241 --> 00:21:39.830
I don't know what that means.

495
00:21:39.830 --> 00:21:41.569
And I don't know what my vision of it is.

496
00:21:41.569 --> 00:21:44.311
If I automate the deployment of IT
services, optimize IT operations,

497
00:21:44.311 --> 00:21:46.155
these are the things
that they're telling me.

498
00:21:46.155 --> 00:21:47.399
These are marketing terms,
marketing jargon.

499
00:21:47.399 --> 00:21:47.955
>> Yeah.
>> So

500
00:21:47.955 --> 00:21:50.695
we've got to get a real
vision of what we can do.

501
00:21:50.695 --> 00:21:51.745
I'm not just picking on Dell.

502
00:21:51.745 --> 00:21:53.578
If we go to HP.

503
00:21:53.578 --> 00:21:54.719
Eliminate complexity and

504
00:21:54.719 --> 00:21:57.888
free your infrastructure from
the limitations of dedicated hardware.

505
00:21:57.888 --> 00:22:00.614
Great, I didn't [CROSSTALK]
>> Know had that problem

506
00:22:00.614 --> 00:22:01.606
>> But maybe I do now.

507
00:22:01.606 --> 00:22:02.615
>> Yeah.

508
00:22:02.615 --> 00:22:05.233
>> Wow,
my OnPremises hardware is limiting me.

509
00:22:05.233 --> 00:22:07.622
So we need to make sure
we understand that.

510
00:22:07.622 --> 00:22:10.694
IBM, renovate,
what do we need to renovate.

511
00:22:10.694 --> 00:22:13.032
Renovate your IT infrastructure
to increase capacity and

512
00:22:13.032 --> 00:22:13.990
reduce storage costs.

513
00:22:13.990 --> 00:22:16.198
All right, well,
I can reduce storage costs, that's good.

514
00:22:16.198 --> 00:22:16.793
>> That's nice.
>> And

515
00:22:16.793 --> 00:22:18.939
so how is that going to look for us?

516
00:22:18.939 --> 00:22:20.139
And then lastly,

517
00:22:20.139 --> 00:22:24.868
we can go Lenovo Revolutionize
Storage Economics with Storeselect.

518
00:22:24.868 --> 00:22:29.619
So each of these vendors are really
advertising software to find storage.

519
00:22:29.619 --> 00:22:30.941
But they do it in different way.

520
00:22:30.941 --> 00:22:34.683
Each on is a different solution, we need
to understand what are vision of this is?

521
00:22:34.683 --> 00:22:38.282
What is our perfect world if I had this
technology and how would I use it?

522
00:22:38.282 --> 00:22:42.653
And then I can start to figure out which
one of these guys actually most align with

523
00:22:42.653 --> 00:22:44.490
what it is that I'm trying to do.

524
00:22:44.490 --> 00:22:47.231
And you might find some of them
don't align very well at all.

525
00:22:47.231 --> 00:22:49.994
But if you don't even have your vision
established, that's going to be a problem.

526
00:22:49.994 --> 00:22:52.735
So that's all a part of the scope process.

527
00:22:52.735 --> 00:22:57.119
We need to identify any business
problems and any business opportunities.

528
00:22:57.119 --> 00:23:01.322
Problems are areas that are causing
us pain and that we need to fix.

529
00:23:01.322 --> 00:23:02.986
Areas that are actively hurting us.

530
00:23:02.986 --> 00:23:07.040
Opportunities are areas that
aren't necessarily hurting us but

531
00:23:07.040 --> 00:23:08.447
we could make better.

532
00:23:08.447 --> 00:23:10.655
Maybe my customers are already happy.

533
00:23:10.655 --> 00:23:14.911
But if I can make them even more
happy where's the value on that?

534
00:23:14.911 --> 00:23:17.034
Might mean the customers
stay with me longer.

535
00:23:17.034 --> 00:23:19.700
It may generate word of mouth or
loyalty like you mentioned.

536
00:23:19.700 --> 00:23:24.244
It might bring me more customers and other
people see our customers are already happy

537
00:23:24.244 --> 00:23:26.612
and we did XYZ and
they are now even happier.

538
00:23:26.612 --> 00:23:28.910
Maybe people didn't mind waiting 24 hours.

539
00:23:28.910 --> 00:23:32.320
But when Right Software
deploy software find storage.

540
00:23:32.320 --> 00:23:35.641
And now they create that customer
environment in under a few minutes.

541
00:23:35.641 --> 00:23:39.743
That makes people even more impressed
with what their capabilities are.

542
00:23:39.743 --> 00:23:43.118
These are the things that we evaluate
all right here during the scope step.

543
00:23:43.118 --> 00:23:47.135
>> Well Don you keep using this word we,
we need to do this,

544
00:23:47.135 --> 00:23:48.767
and we need to do that.

545
00:23:48.767 --> 00:23:52.867
That the thing kept popping into my
mind is who exactly is the we that you

546
00:23:52.867 --> 00:23:54.012
are referring to?

547
00:23:54.012 --> 00:23:55.717
>> What's the saying it's you and
the mouse in your pocket or something?

548
00:23:55.717 --> 00:23:57.969
>> [LAUGH]
>> Yeah the mouse in your pocket that's

549
00:23:57.969 --> 00:23:58.531
right [LAUGH].

550
00:23:58.531 --> 00:24:02.441
So we can be several people,
right, at this scope step,

551
00:24:02.441 --> 00:24:05.703
where this is identifying
our business needs.

552
00:24:05.703 --> 00:24:09.278
Some of this can come from just
the regular workers that are down in

553
00:24:09.278 --> 00:24:10.128
the trenches.

554
00:24:10.128 --> 00:24:16.778
This could be our customer,

555
00:24:16.778 --> 00:24:21.211
but a lot of times,

556
00:24:21.211 --> 00:24:27.031
organizations will have

557
00:24:27.031 --> 00:24:32.295
what is called an ETG,

558
00:24:32.295 --> 00:24:39.793
an Emerging Technology Group.

559
00:24:39.793 --> 00:24:43.182
At the scope stage a lot of
this is already set up, and

560
00:24:43.182 --> 00:24:45.657
we may not even have the ETG built yet.

561
00:24:45.657 --> 00:24:47.814
But when we start moving
into the other steps,

562
00:24:47.814 --> 00:24:50.484
it will be the ETG that actually
does the bulk of the work.

563
00:24:50.484 --> 00:24:53.709
In the start, if I don't have an ETG,
this particular project,

564
00:24:53.709 --> 00:24:57.716
the right software group would start
with a software development team, right.

565
00:24:57.716 --> 00:24:59.026
The software development team,

566
00:24:59.026 --> 00:25:01.281
they're the ones who are having
to create the software.

567
00:25:01.281 --> 00:25:03.517
They're the ones who are having to
create these customer environments.

568
00:25:03.517 --> 00:25:06.358
And they are the ones who are recognizing
that storage is the problem.

569
00:25:06.358 --> 00:25:11.819
So they find the issue, they find this
problem to solve and create a vision.

570
00:25:11.819 --> 00:25:16.333
And then we, as a company, establish
an ETG to then take that vision and

571
00:25:16.333 --> 00:25:17.170
run with it.

572
00:25:17.170 --> 00:25:21.785
And run through the rest of these steps to
find the right solution, get it deployed,

573
00:25:21.785 --> 00:25:23.543
and then move on to the next one.

574
00:25:23.543 --> 00:25:27.572
So an emerging technology group is really
the group of people who are gonna do that.

575
00:25:27.572 --> 00:25:31.979
>> All right, so once we've established
our need, how do we pick a solution?

576
00:25:31.979 --> 00:25:34.740
>> All right, so
when it comes to picking a solution,

577
00:25:34.740 --> 00:25:37.645
this is where things get
a little bit tricky, right.

578
00:25:37.645 --> 00:25:42.908
What we need to do is move into the track
step, and in the track step, what we're

579
00:25:42.908 --> 00:25:47.875
doing is seeking out relevant technologies
from a broad range of sources.

580
00:25:47.875 --> 00:25:51.342
Now, that broad range of
sources is really important,

581
00:25:51.342 --> 00:25:56.226
I might have a meeting with a Dell rep,
the Dell rep comes to the office one day.

582
00:25:56.226 --> 00:25:58.610
And says, let me show you what we got,
this is amazing, and

583
00:25:58.610 --> 00:25:59.720
they show you technology.

584
00:25:59.720 --> 00:26:04.248
You're just blown away it aligns with all
of your business needs, it's perfect for

585
00:26:04.248 --> 00:26:05.478
what you want, okay.

586
00:26:05.478 --> 00:26:08.579
You could stop right there and say,
I'm just gonna run with this one, sold.

587
00:26:08.579 --> 00:26:11.734
But just because one vendor has this
perfect solution that you've been

588
00:26:11.734 --> 00:26:15.153
presented with right on day one doesn't
mean that somebody else isn't doing

589
00:26:15.153 --> 00:26:15.693
it better.

590
00:26:15.693 --> 00:26:19.759
You need to evaluate the other
solutions that are out there, and so

591
00:26:19.759 --> 00:26:24.704
in the track phase, this is where we're
actually looking for other solutions.

592
00:26:24.704 --> 00:26:27.836
And we might not even have a specific
problem in mind yet, we do here in

593
00:26:27.836 --> 00:26:31.570
this example, and we know exactly what
we're looking for, but maybe we don't.

594
00:26:31.570 --> 00:26:35.384
Maybe we went through the scope, and
we came up with our business needs, and

595
00:26:35.384 --> 00:26:39.755
now we've just got a whole list of needs,
and I wonder what's out there, right?

596
00:26:39.755 --> 00:26:43.482
And so, we go into track, now we're
seeking out stuff, we may not have a clue,

597
00:26:43.482 --> 00:26:45.948
right, and we just wanna go out and
find something.

598
00:26:45.948 --> 00:26:49.711
Well, when you're seeking
out those technologies,

599
00:26:49.711 --> 00:26:53.572
you can be presented with
a lot of crazy things, right?

600
00:26:53.572 --> 00:26:57.391
Some that are really mature, that are
great products that are ready to deploy,

601
00:26:57.391 --> 00:27:00.185
like Dell, anything they sell
would be a mature product.

602
00:27:00.185 --> 00:27:02.868
But there's a lot of stuff you
might find on Kickstarter,

603
00:27:02.868 --> 00:27:06.943
or Indiegogo, right, that's non-mature,
that you don't know, it's a big risk.

604
00:27:06.943 --> 00:27:08.042
And so for those,

605
00:27:08.042 --> 00:27:12.528
we end up having to be really careful
with what's called the hype cycle.

606
00:27:12.528 --> 00:27:15.518
The hype cycle is kind of
shown here in this chart, and

607
00:27:15.518 --> 00:27:17.650
I know it's a little bit hard to read.

608
00:27:17.650 --> 00:27:24.842
But every emerging technology goes
through a series of phases, the cycle.

609
00:27:24.842 --> 00:27:29.252
And the cycle kind of shows almost really
the level of risk we would have if we

610
00:27:29.252 --> 00:27:31.356
deployed the technology, right?

611
00:27:31.356 --> 00:27:33.066
So let's kinda run
through this real quick,

612
00:27:33.066 --> 00:27:35.417
we start with what's called
an innovation trigger, right?

613
00:27:35.417 --> 00:27:39.272
Somebody has an idea, there's a problem,
I'm gonna fix it, right, what is it,

614
00:27:39.272 --> 00:27:41.328
is it see a need and
fill it, the old saying?

615
00:27:41.328 --> 00:27:44.634
So somebody sees a need and they fill it,
they come up with a solution,

616
00:27:44.634 --> 00:27:45.765
now that's just them.

617
00:27:45.765 --> 00:27:50.174
This is like Steve Jobs and
Steve Wozniak back in the garage,

618
00:27:50.174 --> 00:27:54.849
it's just a small organization,
they come up with a solution.

619
00:27:54.849 --> 00:27:59.960
And then they start to promote it and
get the word out that, hey, we got this

620
00:27:59.960 --> 00:28:05.419
new solution, you really want it, and
you've got this build up that happens.

621
00:28:05.419 --> 00:28:10.633
This whole build up to what's called
the peak of inflated expectations.

622
00:28:10.633 --> 00:28:12.947
If you don't have something in your hand,

623
00:28:12.947 --> 00:28:16.373
it's easy in your mind to build it
up to be more than it would be.

624
00:28:16.373 --> 00:28:19.504
And what happens when you
finally get it in your hands,

625
00:28:19.504 --> 00:28:21.829
you get the trough of disillusionment.

626
00:28:21.829 --> 00:28:24.801
>> I like that, it sounds like a metal
album title or something [LAUGH].

627
00:28:24.801 --> 00:28:29.203
>> It really does, but it's a great
way to describe what happens, though.

628
00:28:29.203 --> 00:28:32.359
Because in your mind you,
build this up as being perfect, and

629
00:28:32.359 --> 00:28:34.984
then as soon as you get it,
boy, it's not as good.

630
00:28:34.984 --> 00:28:38.920
And if you've ever preordered anything, if
you've done a Kickstarter, this happens.

631
00:28:38.920 --> 00:28:42.516
And as a company if you say, you know
what, what if I just waited, what if I

632
00:28:42.516 --> 00:28:46.413
waited, and yeah, everybody was hyping
this up to be the greatest thing ever.

633
00:28:46.413 --> 00:28:49.274
And so by the time we hit the peak,
boy it was the greatest, and

634
00:28:49.274 --> 00:28:53.125
then if I just waited, and let some people
purchase it and then post some reviews and

635
00:28:53.125 --> 00:28:54.627
things, I could have learned.

636
00:28:54.627 --> 00:28:59.018
And it drops way down here, and now we
get what's actually a little bit below

637
00:28:59.018 --> 00:29:02.392
reality, what is really
the experience of this product.

638
00:29:02.392 --> 00:29:05.322
And then after a little while,
we get the scope of enlightenment,

639
00:29:05.322 --> 00:29:08.532
and scope of enlightenment is,
we understand what this product can do.

640
00:29:08.532 --> 00:29:12.133
We understand what its limitations are,
what it's actually capable of,

641
00:29:12.133 --> 00:29:14.316
what our benefits could
be if we deployed it.

642
00:29:14.316 --> 00:29:18.560
And from there, we can move into what's
call the plateau of productivity,

643
00:29:18.560 --> 00:29:19.568
this last stage.

644
00:29:19.568 --> 00:29:23.187
And this is where we can
actually use the technology and

645
00:29:23.187 --> 00:29:27.286
get the most benefit out of it,
with the right expectations.

646
00:29:27.286 --> 00:29:30.259
Now, the challenge with all of this,
because it seems easy, you're like,

647
00:29:30.259 --> 00:29:31.470
I don't need a chart for this.

648
00:29:31.470 --> 00:29:34.023
I'll just wait for
the plateau of productivity,

649
00:29:34.023 --> 00:29:35.736
that's where I'll buy things.

650
00:29:35.736 --> 00:29:39.106
The problem is,
if you can identify something early,

651
00:29:39.106 --> 00:29:42.986
if I know it's going to make it
to the plateau of productivity,

652
00:29:42.986 --> 00:29:47.454
I could get in way early, back in
the peak of inflated expectations, and

653
00:29:47.454 --> 00:29:50.854
actually benefit, and
my competition might do that.

654
00:29:50.854 --> 00:29:54.590
I don't want to ignore a technology too
long and my competition gets in there and

655
00:29:54.590 --> 00:29:56.727
gets the business
advantage out of it first.

656
00:29:56.727 --> 00:29:59.682
So we don't want to ignore
technologies early on, but

657
00:29:59.682 --> 00:30:04.001
we want to make sure we understand where
they're at in this hype cycle, right?

658
00:30:04.001 --> 00:30:08.098
If I see a solution, and I know that it
has not hit the peak of its expectations

659
00:30:08.098 --> 00:30:10.018
yet, if it's not fully inflated,

660
00:30:10.018 --> 00:30:14.451
then I know that there's definitely gonna
be some disappointment down the road.

661
00:30:14.451 --> 00:30:18.108
And as long as we build in for that, build
that expectation in ourselves to say like,

662
00:30:18.108 --> 00:30:20.116
I know this isn't gonna
be as good as they say,

663
00:30:20.116 --> 00:30:23.019
then you can still make responsible
decisions around it, right?

664
00:30:23.019 --> 00:30:26.831
But we need to understand where it falls,
and the other risk here is that some

665
00:30:26.831 --> 00:30:29.643
products never make it to
the plateau of productivity.

666
00:30:29.643 --> 00:30:33.435
Sometimes the fall of expectations is so

667
00:30:33.435 --> 00:30:38.240
great that the business closes down,
that's it.

668
00:30:38.240 --> 00:30:43.133
Maybe it's really bad, there's false
advertising involved and now lawsuits.

669
00:30:43.133 --> 00:30:46.114
Things can happen to stop it from
ever making it to that plateau.

670
00:30:46.114 --> 00:30:49.898
And if you got invested early in it, now
that's going to be a loss for you, right?

671
00:30:49.898 --> 00:30:52.694
>> Well, where on this line is
supposed to be the pain of litigation?

672
00:30:52.694 --> 00:30:56.629
>> [LAUGH] The pain of litigation,
that probably spreads the whole thing.

673
00:30:56.629 --> 00:31:00.568
The other thing about this,
some technologies, it's not that they ever

674
00:31:00.568 --> 00:31:04.523
make it to the plateau of productivity,
but a better option comes along.

675
00:31:04.523 --> 00:31:08.123
They're still moving on, you see,
this process may take years,

676
00:31:08.123 --> 00:31:11.337
sometimes it takes, a device,
an application software,

677
00:31:11.337 --> 00:31:14.829
it takes years to get all the way
to the plateau of productivity.

678
00:31:14.829 --> 00:31:17.366
In the meantime,
some competition comes along and

679
00:31:17.366 --> 00:31:21.145
just cleans their house, a disruptive
technology, right, comes along.

680
00:31:21.145 --> 00:31:25.325
And now they become obsolete,
before they even made it through,

681
00:31:25.325 --> 00:31:27.608
that happens, that happens a lot.

682
00:31:27.608 --> 00:31:31.086
We're seeing that now where
hybrid cars had their moment, but

683
00:31:31.086 --> 00:31:33.130
now all electric cars are coming in.

684
00:31:33.130 --> 00:31:38.000
And you're like, why buy a hybrid, I'll
go all electric, so that happens a lot.

685
00:31:38.000 --> 00:31:40.760

912
00:42:58.388 --> 00:43:00.756
the harder it is to make that decision,
right?

913
00:43:00.756 --> 00:43:04.534
>> Yes, definitely, I've had plenty of
managers that are just sitting there

914
00:43:04.534 --> 00:43:08.090
going, well should we go with this,
but this offers a little bit more.

915
00:43:08.090 --> 00:43:12.473
And they just can't pull the trigger,
and it's like you know what we're coming

916
00:43:12.473 --> 00:43:15.825
to the part where you just need
to make one of these and go okay,

917
00:43:15.825 --> 00:43:17.841
I like that one better than this one.

918
00:43:17.841 --> 00:43:21.567
A lot of times it does come down to, this
one has a little bit more of this, but

919
00:43:21.567 --> 00:43:23.451
this one has a little bit more of that.

920
00:43:23.451 --> 00:43:26.709
Which one do you like and you just
gotta kinda like make that happen,

921
00:43:26.709 --> 00:43:29.927
otherwise you'll, like you said,
get frozen with indecision.

922
00:43:29.927 --> 00:43:32.560
>> Right.
Now depending on your economic risk right,

923
00:43:32.560 --> 00:43:36.093
the more expensive the technology is
the more you wanna put into this.

924
00:43:36.093 --> 00:43:39.537
So the way you make this decision
could be as simple as research, right,

925
00:43:39.537 --> 00:43:41.238
I just do research, and I find out.

926
00:43:41.238 --> 00:43:43.952
I might go a step further and
do a prototype, right.

927
00:43:43.952 --> 00:43:47.804
Let's get an evaluation, let's do
a sample, and a test and actually deploy,

928
00:43:47.804 --> 00:43:48.909
and see what we can do.

929
00:43:48.909 --> 00:43:52.723
We might do a full on pilot, I might say,
you know what let me take 5% of my

930
00:43:52.723 --> 00:43:55.263
customer base and
try them out in this solution.

931
00:43:55.263 --> 00:44:00.054
I'll leave the other 95% on the regular
solution, and then that way I can compare.

932
00:44:00.054 --> 00:44:02.758
That way we dip our toes in, and
just kinda see how it goes, and

933
00:44:02.758 --> 00:44:03.656
evaluate, right.

934
00:44:03.656 --> 00:44:06.360
That's all a part of this evaluate step,
right.

935
00:44:06.360 --> 00:44:10.781
We're just trying it out, we're trying
to find the benefits, the costs, and

936
00:44:10.781 --> 00:44:11.448
the risks.

937
00:44:11.448 --> 00:44:13.813
And make sure we actually
have those hammered down and

938
00:44:13.813 --> 00:44:15.032
understand what they are.

939
00:44:15.032 --> 00:44:18.605
Not just this nebulous idea of risk,
but like an actual number,

940
00:44:18.605 --> 00:44:22.652
that hey if we deployed this and
it fails we could lose $1.3 million.

941
00:44:22.652 --> 00:44:25.517
Or we wouldn't lose anything,
there's no risk at all,

942
00:44:25.517 --> 00:44:28.096
you wanna make sure you
actually know what that is.

943
00:44:28.096 --> 00:44:31.800
And then once you've got all that
information you can make the ultimate

944
00:44:31.800 --> 00:44:32.427
decision.

945
00:44:32.427 --> 00:44:35.488
And there's really just three
possible decisions here,

946
00:44:35.488 --> 00:44:38.117
you can choose to adopt
the emerging technology.

947
00:44:38.117 --> 00:44:39.719
You can say, yes we're gonna do it,
we're going to deploy it.

948
00:44:39.719 --> 00:44:42.531
Or you can choose not to adopt it,
you can say nope, we're not doing that,

949
00:44:42.531 --> 00:44:43.301
that's a bad idea.

950
00:44:43.301 --> 00:44:47.952
Or you can choose to shelve it, and
say you know what let me let this wait,

951
00:44:47.952 --> 00:44:51.406
it's in the hype cycle,
it's not in the right spot.

952
00:44:51.406 --> 00:44:54.815
Maybe I want to wait a little bit,
and I'm gonna see how it goes for

953
00:44:54.815 --> 00:44:55.871
some other people.

954
00:44:55.871 --> 00:44:58.591
Maybe my competitors are deploying it, but
I can see that they're making mistakes,

955
00:44:58.591 --> 00:44:59.777
and it's not working well for them.

956
00:44:59.777 --> 00:45:03.338
I might want to wait just a little bit,
and see what mistakes they make, so

957
00:45:03.338 --> 00:45:05.071
I can avoid those mistakes myself.

958
00:45:05.071 --> 00:45:07.297
It's always better to learn from
somebody else's mistakes, right.

959
00:45:07.297 --> 00:45:07.969
>> Yeah.

960
00:45:07.969 --> 00:45:10.035
>> So that's all a part of this,
but when it's done,

961
00:45:10.035 --> 00:45:11.537
we'll make one of those decisions.

962
00:45:11.537 --> 00:45:14.510
And if we decide not to adopt that's
the end of the street process,

963
00:45:14.510 --> 00:45:15.423
we're done right?

964
00:45:15.423 --> 00:45:17.661
>> [LAUGH]
>> If we decide to shelve it,

965
00:45:17.661 --> 00:45:18.641
then we just wait.

966
00:45:18.641 --> 00:45:23.476
But if we decide to adopt that technology,
then we're ready to move on,

967
00:45:23.476 --> 00:45:24.997
and get things going.

968
00:45:24.997 --> 00:45:28.580
>> So Don what does the ETG do after
they have selected a technology?

969
00:45:28.580 --> 00:45:32.416
>> Here's where that evangelist comes
in right, so the ETG has done its job.

970
00:45:32.416 --> 00:45:34.405
>> Right.
>> Technically the ETG's job is done

971
00:45:34.405 --> 00:45:35.929
when they select the technology.

972
00:45:35.929 --> 00:45:40.990
So we're going to deploy software defined
storage with Amazon Web Services,

973
00:45:40.990 --> 00:45:44.143
okay well now somebody's
actually got to do it.

974
00:45:44.143 --> 00:45:48.088
And the ETG is made up of a lot of people
who are not necessarily the people who

975
00:45:48.088 --> 00:45:49.664
will actually do the change.

976
00:45:49.664 --> 00:45:52.171
So this is where you bring
in an evangelist, and

977
00:45:52.171 --> 00:45:55.505
if this a full on project there'll
often be a project manager.

978
00:45:55.505 --> 00:45:58.953
Somebody who's gonna take on this
project of deploying our customer

979
00:45:58.953 --> 00:46:01.154
virtual environment inside of Amazon AWS,

980
00:46:01.154 --> 00:46:04.611
and actually rolling forward that
project to get us moved over to it.

981
00:46:04.611 --> 00:46:06.918
But if it's simply buying
a piece of hardware,

982
00:46:06.918 --> 00:46:10.324
then you're evangelist will usually
just be the operational manager

983
00:46:10.324 --> 00:46:13.053
who runs the department that
will receive that device.

984
00:46:13.053 --> 00:46:15.230
It varies what that's going to look like.

985
00:46:15.230 --> 00:46:17.887
But that's where the evangelist comes in,

986
00:46:17.887 --> 00:46:21.346
that hopefully we have chosen
during our evaluate step.

987
00:46:21.346 --> 00:46:25.432
But now we're in the evangelize, and
in evangelize we inspire, educate, and

988
00:46:25.432 --> 00:46:26.966
involve other people right.

989
00:46:26.966 --> 00:46:31.068
All the other people in our company, to
obtain the cooperation and support of all

990
00:46:31.068 --> 00:46:35.068
those who will influence the successful
adoption of the technology,right.

991
00:46:35.068 --> 00:46:37.325
That last part is really important here,

992
00:46:37.325 --> 00:46:40.359
these people will influence
the successful adoption.

993
00:46:40.359 --> 00:46:44.002
You may have found the perfect solution,
it improves your, or

994
00:46:44.002 --> 00:46:48.062
it meets your business needs,
it improves your customer happiness,

995
00:46:48.062 --> 00:46:51.050
it lowers your cost,
it makes you more efficient.

996
00:46:51.050 --> 00:46:55.532
But if you're end users are resistant to
it for some reason, then you're gonna end

997
00:46:55.532 --> 00:46:59.581
up in the situation where you don't
make use of it and you ultimately fail.

998
00:46:59.581 --> 00:47:03.360
>> I actually worked for company where
they implemented a project management

999
00:47:03.360 --> 00:47:07.381
system that they spent tons of money
developing, designing,getting it, and

1000
00:47:07.381 --> 00:47:09.612
they said this is what
we're gonna use now.

1001
00:47:09.612 --> 00:47:13.561
And everybody hated it, they hated so
much, and refused to use it, and so

1002
00:47:13.561 --> 00:47:16.943
it actually went back to their
old project management system,

1003
00:47:16.943 --> 00:47:18.631
cuz no one would use the thing.

1004
00:47:18.631 --> 00:47:20.987
>> Yeah, and that's,
that can be a culture problem,

1005
00:47:20.987 --> 00:47:23.464
that can be having the right
people in the right place.

1006
00:47:23.464 --> 00:47:26.045
But when you have a good evangelist,
somebody who can go out and

1007
00:47:26.045 --> 00:47:28.696
talk to people and say,
let me explain to you why we picked this.

1008
00:47:28.696 --> 00:47:30.725
Let me show you how this
makes your job easier,

1009
00:47:30.725 --> 00:47:32.766
let me show you how this
makes your job better.

1010
00:47:32.766 --> 00:47:36.108
When you have somebody explaining that,
it really makes a difference.

1011
00:47:36.108 --> 00:47:40.113
Now we're not gonna get into it here,
we've already gone long enough, but

1012
00:47:40.113 --> 00:47:42.431
there are different types of evangelists,

1013
00:47:42.431 --> 00:47:45.134
cuz an evangelist can reign
down with an iron fist.

1014
00:47:45.134 --> 00:47:46.151
>> Yeah.

1015
00:47:46.151 --> 00:47:48.232
Different types,
different ways of problem solving.

1016
00:47:48.232 --> 00:47:51.849
But ultimately the evangelist is
trying to make sure, That everybody

1017
00:47:51.849 --> 00:47:55.172
has buy in on this solution, and
everyone runs forward with it.

1018
00:47:55.172 --> 00:47:58.027
>> Well Don,
does the champion then, take over?

1019
00:47:58.027 --> 00:48:01.151
>> Yeah, now, who the champion is,
is a bit of a mystery, right?

1020
00:48:01.151 --> 00:48:02.346
We're not sure who that's going to be.

1021
00:48:02.346 --> 00:48:08.972
But at this point, there And the ETG
now can do what's called transferring.

1022
00:48:08.972 --> 00:48:10.699
It's our final step is transfer, and

1023
00:48:10.699 --> 00:48:13.137
that's where the ETG kinda
washes our hands of this.

1024
00:48:13.137 --> 00:48:14.740
And they say okay, we're done,

1025
00:48:14.740 --> 00:48:18.535
we've gotta move on cuz there's other
technologies we've gotta evaluate.

1026
00:48:18.535 --> 00:48:22.345
So with transfer, we transfer
responsibility for a new technology to

1027
00:48:22.345 --> 00:48:27.140
another department or project that will
take it to full-scale deployment, alright?

1028
00:48:27.140 --> 00:48:29.487
They take it and run with it.

1029
00:48:29.487 --> 00:48:33.309
If it's software to find storage, somebody
down on the development team will be

1030
00:48:33.309 --> 00:48:35.291
the person that helms that, runs for it.

1031
00:48:35.291 --> 00:48:36.631
And actually gets
the stuff moving forward.

1032
00:48:36.631 --> 00:48:38.409
The project [INAUDIBLE]
not the project manager.

1033
00:48:38.409 --> 00:48:41.250
But the ETG transfers over to them.

1034
00:48:41.250 --> 00:48:45.170
And then, says, okay, now, we're going
to go way back to the beginning,

1035
00:48:45.170 --> 00:48:47.454
when we were doing scope and track, right?

1036
00:48:47.454 --> 00:48:48.767
So we just deployed this new technology.

1037
00:48:48.767 --> 00:48:50.895
Does our scope change, it might.

1038
00:48:50.895 --> 00:48:53.674
Right we might have new business
needs now as a result of having this

1039
00:48:53.674 --> 00:48:54.628
technology in place.

1040
00:48:54.628 --> 00:48:58.034
And then, our track, we're looking for
new solutions, all right?

1041
00:48:58.034 --> 00:49:01.142
Maybe there's something that can make this
one better because this process might have

1042
00:49:01.142 --> 00:49:01.663
taken years.

1043
00:49:01.663 --> 00:49:03.635
And now when we start our next one,

1044
00:49:03.635 --> 00:49:06.292
we might all ready have
the next thing in line.

1045
00:49:06.292 --> 00:49:07.622
We just finished deploying this, but

1046
00:49:07.622 --> 00:49:09.380
the next thing in line is
all ready on the horizon.

1047
00:49:09.380 --> 00:49:11.091
So, we start looking at it and
moving forward.

1048
00:49:11.091 --> 00:49:13.659
But we need to free up
the ETG to do what they do.

1049
00:49:13.659 --> 00:49:15.521
And it may be that one or two or

1050
00:49:15.521 --> 00:49:20.428
maybe even all the members of the ETG
go on to do the actual implementation.

1051
00:49:20.428 --> 00:49:23.410
And we build a whole new ETG,
with all new employees.

1052
00:49:23.410 --> 00:49:26.233
It's not ideal, cause a lot of
retraining and re-education, but

1053
00:49:26.233 --> 00:49:27.678
then that is certainly possible.

1054
00:49:27.678 --> 00:49:30.485
And now they roll forward without
actually moving forward, but

1055
00:49:30.485 --> 00:49:32.781
that's really what the transfer
step is all about.

1056
00:49:32.781 --> 00:49:36.772
But when that's all said and done,
we've completed the street process.

1057
00:49:36.772 --> 00:49:40.303
We've moved through all six steps,
we made smart decisions,

1058
00:49:40.303 --> 00:49:43.978
we evaluated the technologies,
we chose them, we deploy them.

1059
00:49:43.978 --> 00:49:45.590
Hopefully, deployed them successfully.

1060
00:49:45.590 --> 00:49:48.012
And now we're just evaluating
what's next on the horizon.

1061
00:49:48.012 --> 00:49:52.768
And by doing this we've hopefully
avoided selecting technologies

1062
00:49:52.768 --> 00:49:55.026
that were unneccessary risks.

1063
00:49:55.026 --> 00:49:57.849
That were not where they needed to be for
us to accept them and

1064
00:49:57.849 --> 00:49:59.046
move forward with them.

1065
00:49:59.046 --> 00:50:01.598
>> All right well Don it was a great
look at the Gartner Street Process.

1066
00:50:01.598 --> 00:50:04.960
We do appreciate you walking us through
that, holding our little hands.

1067
00:50:04.960 --> 00:50:07.497
So that we'll understand
it a little bit better and

1068
00:50:07.497 --> 00:50:09.392
maybe be better at our process there.

1069
00:50:09.392 --> 00:50:12.531
And that being said, I'm looking at our
clock though, we are out of time for

1070
00:50:12.531 --> 00:50:13.183
this episode.

1071
00:50:13.183 --> 00:50:16.720
We do thank our audience out there for
watching but signing off for

1072
00:50:16.720 --> 00:50:19.844
ITPROTV I've been your host Daniel Lowry
>> And I'm Don Pezet

1073
00:50:19.844 --> 00:50:28.372
>> And we'll see you next time.

1074
00:50:28.372 --> 00:50:31.340
Thank you for watching ITProTV.,

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don help you more thoroughly understand the Gartner STREET process through example. Here they play the part of the fictional "Dapper Clothing" company and employ the STREET process to help them implement IoT (Internet-of-Things) into their current business model.
episodes.title: STREET Process Example
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.001 --> 00:00:02.721
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.721 --> 00:00:06.433
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.433 --> 00:00:08.177
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.177 --> 00:00:11.520
>> You're watching IT ProTV.

5
00:00:11.520 --> 00:00:13.544
>> All right, greetings everyone and

6
00:00:13.544 --> 00:00:16.657
welcome back to another
exciting episode of ITProTV.

7
00:00:16.657 --> 00:00:20.285
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie, and
in today's episode we are back to taking

8
00:00:20.285 --> 00:00:22.486
another look at our
Gartner STREET process.

9
00:00:22.486 --> 00:00:25.760
And joining us back in the studio yet
again is our good friend, Mr. Don Pezet.

10
00:00:25.760 --> 00:00:27.179
Don, welcome back to the show,
how's it going today?

11
00:00:27.179 --> 00:00:28.990
>> It is going great Daniel,
thanks for having me back.

12
00:00:28.990 --> 00:00:30.578
And that the last episode,

13
00:00:30.578 --> 00:00:34.252
we got a chance to really do a deep
dive into the STREET process.

14
00:00:34.252 --> 00:00:38.579
What each step along that framework was,
and what a company is expected to do.

15
00:00:38.579 --> 00:00:41.125
In this episode we wanna
be a little bit different.

16
00:00:41.125 --> 00:00:43.187
We're gonna go a little more brief and

17
00:00:43.187 --> 00:00:47.442
I wanna give you guys kind of a real world
example, an example of how a company or

18
00:00:47.442 --> 00:00:50.748
organization would move through
this to support a product.

19
00:00:50.748 --> 00:00:54.014
In the last one we did
the Write Software incorporated,

20
00:00:54.014 --> 00:00:57.012
they created that software for
home inspections.

21
00:00:57.012 --> 00:00:58.647
In this one,
we're gonna use a different company.

22
00:00:58.647 --> 00:01:01.992
We're gonna use
Dapper Clothing Incorporated,

23
00:01:01.992 --> 00:01:07.180
a clothing retailer that has mall stores
all over the world or US or wherever.

24
00:01:07.180 --> 00:01:11.324
And they're going through this process
of evaluating emerging technologies and

25
00:01:11.324 --> 00:01:13.967
figuring out how they're
going to be implemented or

26
00:01:13.967 --> 00:01:16.199
if they're going to be implemented at all.

27
00:01:16.199 --> 00:01:19.257
But the key thing here is I wanted to
give you a real example and kind of move

28
00:01:19.257 --> 00:01:22.717
the teaching piece off and just go right
into here's how it works, so that you guys

29
00:01:22.717 --> 00:01:26.105
have a good understanding of what it's
kind of like out there in the real world.

30
00:01:26.105 --> 00:01:28.890
So that's what we've got lined
up right here in this episode.

31
00:01:28.890 --> 00:01:30.912
>> All right Don,
you set a bit of a stage for us.

32
00:01:30.912 --> 00:01:34.712
But what is the actual idea?

33
00:01:34.712 --> 00:01:36.073
What is the scenario here?

34
00:01:36.073 --> 00:01:39.770
>> All right, well we have to kind of
have of process that gets initiated.

35
00:01:39.770 --> 00:01:42.977
So somebody in the company somewhere,
you have this company that exists.

36
00:01:42.977 --> 00:01:43.670
>> Right.

37
00:01:43.670 --> 00:01:47.165
And someone in that company gets an idea,
an idea that, hey,

38
00:01:47.165 --> 00:01:51.617
there's something we should be doing
to make our experience better, right?

39
00:01:51.617 --> 00:01:53.831
And that idea could come
from any number of places.

40
00:01:53.831 --> 00:01:55.232
It could come just
straight from their head.

41
00:01:55.232 --> 00:01:57.431
Maybe they just thought of something
that pops into their mind.

42
00:01:57.431 --> 00:01:58.940
Like maybe we should
really look into that.

43
00:01:58.940 --> 00:02:01.980
Or maybe it's a documented
need of the company.

44
00:02:01.980 --> 00:02:05.188
Or more commonly, they're out there
on the Internet or whatever and

45
00:02:05.188 --> 00:02:06.966
they come across an article, right?

46
00:02:06.966 --> 00:02:11.105
I've got an example here on my screen
that maybe they're out there browsing and

47
00:02:11.105 --> 00:02:13.205
they've seen an article like this one,

48
00:02:13.205 --> 00:02:16.510
The Internet of Things Revolutionizing
the Retail Industry.

49
00:02:16.510 --> 00:02:19.462
Now, even if you don't know
what this article is about,

50
00:02:19.462 --> 00:02:22.798
if you work in the retail industry
what does this make you think?

51
00:02:22.798 --> 00:02:23.936
>> Maybe I need to do this.

52
00:02:23.936 --> 00:02:27.102
>> Yeah, we're gonna get
revolutionized out of the business.

53
00:02:27.102 --> 00:02:30.189
Somebody else is getting this competitive
advantage and we're gonna miss out.

54
00:02:30.189 --> 00:02:32.877
And so, this peaks interest.

55
00:02:32.877 --> 00:02:35.555
It gets people thinking
that they have something

56
00:02:35.555 --> 00:02:37.524
out there that they need to deploy.

57
00:02:37.524 --> 00:02:40.928
Their customer experience,
supply chain, new channels and revenue,

58
00:02:40.928 --> 00:02:43.730
all these different things
are out there waiting for them.

59
00:02:43.730 --> 00:02:44.595
>> Shoot, I'm exited.

60
